standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Area & perimeter of rectangles word problems

question.content: Margo wants to build a rectangular fence around her garden, and she has $24$ meters of wood.  **Which of these dimensions will give Margo the largest area?**

hints.content: Let's find the area of each rectangle to see which one has the largest area.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$
###$8$ meters by $4$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD8\text{ m}\times\blueD4\text{ m} = 32\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 4 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 8 meters.

hints.content: ###$10$ meters by $2$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD{10}\text{ m}\times\blueD2\text{ m} = 20\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 2 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 10 meters.

hints.content: ###$6$ meters by $6$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD{6}\text{ m}\times\blueD6\text{ m} = 36\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with all four sides labeled 6 meters.

hints.content: The garden with the dimensions of $6\text{ meters}$ by $6\text{ meters}$ has the largest area.

question.content: Jordan wants to create a rectangular border around his classroom bulletin board, and he has $30$ meters of border.  **Which of these dimensions will give Jordan the largest area?**

hints.content: Let's find the area of each rectangle to see which one has the largest area.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$
###$10$ meters by $5$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD{10}\text{ m}\times\blueD5\text{ m} = 50\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 5 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 10 meters.

hints.content: ###$7$ meters by $8$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD{8}\text{ m}\times\blueD7\text{ m} = 56\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 7 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 8 meters.

hints.content: ###$12$ meters by $3$ meters   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Area}=\greenD{12}\text{ m}\times\blueD3\text{ m} = 36\text{ square meters}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 3 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 12 meters.

hints.content: The bulletin board with the dimensions of $8\text{ meters}$ by $7\text{ meters}$ has the largest area.

question.content: Chloe has enough sand to fill a rectangular sandbox with an area of $36$ square units. She wants the outer edges of the sandbox to use as little material as possible.  **Which dimensions will give Chloe the smallest perimeter?**

hints.content: Let's find the perimeter of each rectangle to see which one has the smallest perimeter.  $\text{Perimeter} = \text{length} + \text{width} +  \text{length} + \text{width}$
###$6$ units by $6$ units   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Perimeter}=\greenD{6}\text{ u}+\blueD6\text{ u} + \greenD{6}\text{ u}+\blueD6\text{ u} = 24\text{ units}$

images.alt: A rectangle with all four sides labeled 6 units.

hints.content: ###$9$ units by $4$ units  [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Perimeter}=\greenD{9}\text{ u}+\blueD4\text{ u} + \greenD{9}\text{ u}+\blueD4\text{ u} = 26\text{ units}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 4 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 9 units.

hints.content: ###$12$ units by $3$ units   [[☃ image 1]]  $\text{Perimeter}=\greenD{12}\text{ u}+\blueD3\text{ u} + \greenD{12}\text{ u}+\blueD3\text{ u} = 30\text{ units}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 3 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 12 units.

hints.content: $24\text{ u} < 26\text{ u}< 30\text{ u}$
A rectanglar sandbox with the dimensions of $6\text{ units}$ by $6\text{ units}$ has the smallest perimeter.

question.content: The area of a square is $144$ square centimeters.    **What is the length of one side of the square?**     centimeters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.   $\text{Area of a square} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the square is $\goldE{144}$ square centimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}\\\\ \goldE{144} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s} \end{align}$

images.alt: A square with all four sides labeled s. Inside the square, it says 144 square centimeters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by itself to get $\goldE{144}$?  $\goldE{144}=\greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}$
The length of one side of the square is $\greenD{12}$ centimeters.

question.content: A square has an area of $100$ square meters.  **What is the perimeter of the square?**   meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.   $\text{Area of a square} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the square is $\goldE{100}$ square meters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}\\\\ \goldE{100\text{ square m}} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s} \end{align}$

images.alt: A square with all four sides labeled s. Inside the square, it says 100 square meters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by itself to get $\goldE{100}$?  $\goldE{100}=\greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}$  The length of each side is $10$ meters.

Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ side}} + \blueD{\text{ side}} +  \greenD{\text{ side}} + \blueD{\text{ side}}\\\\ &=\greenD{10} + \blueD{10} + \greenD{10} + \blueD{10}\\\\ &=40 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the square is $40$ meters.

question.content: A square has an area of $49$ square meters.  **What is the perimeter of the square?**   meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.   $\text{Area of a square} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the square is $\goldE{49}$ square meters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}\\\\ \goldE{49\text{ square m}} &= \greenD{s}\times\blueD{s} \end{align}$

images.alt: A square with all four sides labeled s. Inside the square, it says 49 square meters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by itself to get $\goldE{49}$?  $\goldE{49}=\greenD{s}\times\blueD{s}$  The length of each side is $7$ meters.

Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ side}} + \blueD{\text{ side}} +  \greenD{\text{ side}} + \blueD{\text{ side}}\\\\ &=\greenD7 + \blueD7 + \greenD7 + \blueD7\\\\ &=28 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the square is $28$ meters.

question.content: Steve built a square hamster pen that has a perimeter of $240$ centimeters.  **What is the length of one side of Steve's hamster pen?**   centimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter of the square is $\purpleD{240}\text{ cm}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{240} &=  \greenD{s}  + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{240} &= 4 \times s \end{align}$

images.alt: A square with all four sides unlabeled. Under the square, it says Perimeter equals 240 centimeters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by $4$ to get $\purpleD{240}$?
We can divide to find the side length.    $\purpleD{240}\div4= \blueD{\text{s}}$
One side of the hamster pen is $\blueD{60}$ centimeters.

question.content: The perimeter of Jonah's square backyard is $56$ meters.  **What is the area of Jonah's backyard?**   square meters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter of the square is $\purpleD{56}\text{ m}$.  [[☃ image 1]]    $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{56} &=  \greenD{s}  + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{56} &= 4 \times s \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with all four sides unlabeled. Under the square, it says Perimeter equals 56 meters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by $4$ to get $\purpleD{56}$?
We can divide to find the side length.    $\begin{align} \purpleD{56}\div4 = \blueD{\text{s}}\\\\ 14=\blueD{\text{s}} \end{align}$

Now, we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side} \times \text{side}\\\\ &= \blueD{s} \times \blueD{s}\\\\ &= \blueD{14} \times \blueD{14}\\\\ &= 196\text{ square meters} \end{align}$
The area of Jonah's backyard is $196$ square meters.

question.content: A square has a perimeter of $36$ millimeters.  **What is the area of the square?**   square millimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter of the square is $\purpleD{36}\text{ mm}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{36} &=  \greenD{s}  + \greenD{s} + \blueD{s} + \blueD{s}\\\\ \purpleD{36} &= 4 \times s \end{align}$

images.alt: A square with all four sides unlabeled. Under the square, it says Perimeter equals 36 millimeters.

hints.content: What number can we multiply by $4$ to get $\purpleD{36}$?
We can divide to find the side length.    $\begin{align} \purpleD{36}\div4 = \blueD{\text{s}}\\\\ 9=\blueD{\text{s}} \end{align}$
Now, we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side} \times \text{side}\\\\ &= \blueD{s} \times \blueD{s}\\\\ &= \blueD{9} \times \blueD{9}\\\\ &= 81\text{ square mm} \end{align}$
The area of the square is $81$ square millimeters.

question.content: The area of a rectangle is $117$ square meters.  The width is $9$ meters.  **What is the length of the rectangle?**     meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the rectangle is $\goldE{117}$ square meters and the $\blueD{\text{width}}$ is $\blueD{9}$ meters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{\ell}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{117} &= \greenD{\ell}\times\blueD{9}\\\\ \goldE{117}\div\blueD9&=\greenD{\ell} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 9 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled l. Inside the rectangle, it says 117 meters squared.

hints.content: The length of the rectangle is $\greenD{13}$ meters.

question.content: Jason built a rectangular tool shed that is $8$ meters wide and has an area of $96$ square meters.    **What is the length of Jason’s tool shed?**   meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the rectangle is $\goldE{96}$ square meters and the $\blueD{\text{width}}$ is $\blueD{8}$ meters.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{\ell}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{96} &= \greenD{\ell}\times\blueD{8}\\\\ \goldE{96}\div\blueD8&=\greenD{\ell} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 8 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled l. Inside the rectangle, it says 96 meters squared.

hints.content: The length of the tool shed is $\greenD{12}$ meters.

question.content: The area of a rectangle is $28$ square meters.  The length is $7$ meters.  **What is the width of the rectangle?**     meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{height}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the rectangle is $\goldE{28}$ square meters and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $\greenD{7}$ meters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{7}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{28} &= \greenD{7}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{28}\div\greenD7&=\blueD{w} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled w and both the top and bottom each labeled 7 meters. Inside the rectangle, it says 28 meters squared.

hints.content: The width of the rectangle is $\blueD{4}$ meters.

question.content: Elise built a large rectangular vegetable garden that is $9$ meters long and has an area of $72$ square meters.    **What is the perimeter of Elise’s vegetable garden?**   meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the rectangle is $\goldE{72}$ square meters and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $\greenD{9}$ meters.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{9}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{72} &= \greenD{9}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{72}\div\greenD9&=\blueD{w}\\\\ \blueD8&=\blueD{w} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled w and both the top and bottom each labeled 9 meters. Inside the rectangle, it says 72 meters squared.

hints.content: Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}} +  \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}}\\\\ &=\greenD9 + \blueD8 + \greenD9 + \blueD8\\\\ &=34 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the garden is $34$ meters.

question.content: The area of a rectangle is $42$ square millimeters.  The length is $7$ millimeters.  **What is the perimeter of the rectangle?**     millimeters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.  $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$

The **$\goldE{\text{area}}$** of the rectangle is $\goldE{42}$ square millimeters and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $\greenD{7}$ millimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{area}} &= \greenD{7}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{42} &= \greenD{7}\times\blueD{w}\\\\ \goldE{42}\div\greenD7&=\blueD{w}\\\\ \blueD6&=\blueD{w} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled w and both the top and bottom each labeled 7 millimeters. Inside the rectangle, it says 42 millimeters squared.

hints.content: Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}} +  \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}}\\\\ &=\greenD7 + \blueD6 + \greenD7 + \blueD6\\\\ &=26 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $26$ millimeters.

question.content: Judy built a rectangular patio that is $9$ meters wide and has a perimeter of $40$ meters.    **What is the length of Judy's patio?**   meters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter is $\purpleD{40}\text{ m}$ and the width is $\blueD{9}\text{ m}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{l} + \blueD{w} + \greenD{l} + \blueD{w}\\\\ \purpleD{40} &= \greenD{\ell} + \blueD9 +  \greenD{\ell} + \blueD9 \\\\ \purpleD{40} &=  \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} + \blueD{18}\\\\ 22 &= \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 9 meters. Under the rectangle, it says Perimeter equals 40 meters.

hints.content: What number can we add twice to get $22$?
The length of the patio is $\greenD{11}$ meters.

question.content: The perimeter of a rectangle is $90$ centimeters.  The length is $27$ centimeters.  **What is the width of the rectangle?**     centimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter is $\purpleD{90}\text{ cm}$ and the length is $\greenD{27}\text{ cm}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{l} + \blueD{w} + \greenD{l} + \blueD{w}\\\\ \purpleD{90} &= \greenD{27} + \blueD{w} +  \greenD{27} + \blueD{w} \\\\ \purpleD{90} &=  \greenD{54} + \blueD{w} + \blueD{w}\\\\ 36 &=  \blueD{w} + \blueD{w} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled w and both the top and bottom each labeled 27 centimeters. Under the rectangle, it says Perimeter equals 90 centimeters.

hints.content: What number can we add twice to get $36$?
The width of the rectangle is $\blueD{18}$ centimeters.

question.content: Lisa built a rectangular flower garden that is $4$ meters wide and has a perimeter of $26$ meters.    **What is the length of Lisa's flower garden?**   meters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter is $\purpleD{26}\text{ m}$ and the width is $\blueD{4}\text{ m}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{l} + \blueD{w} + \greenD{l} + \blueD{w}\\\\ \purpleD{26} &= \greenD{\ell} + \blueD4 +  \greenD{\ell} + \blueD4 \\\\ \purpleD{26} &=  \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} + \blueD{8}\\\\ 18&= \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 4 meters. Under the rectangle, it says Perimeter equals 26 meters.

hints.content: What number can we add twice to get $18$?
The length of the flower garden is $\greenD{9}$ meters.

question.content: The perimeter of a rectangle is $20$ centimeters.  The length is $6$ centimeters.  **What is the area of the rectangle?**     square centimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter is $\purpleD{20}\text{ cm}$ and the length is $\greenD{6}\text{ cm}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{l} + \blueD{w} + \greenD{l} + \blueD{w}\\\\ \purpleD{20} &= \greenD{6} + \blueD{w} +  \greenD{6} + \blueD{w} \\\\ \purpleD{20} &=  \blueD{w}  + \blueD{w} + \greenD{12}\\\\ 8&= \blueD{w} + \blueD{w} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the top and bottom sides each labeled 6 centimeters. Under the rectangle, it says Perimeter equals 20 centimeters.

hints.content: What number can we add twice to get $8$?  The width of the rectangle is $\blueD{4}$ centimeters.
Now, we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \greenD{\text{length}} \times \blueD{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \greenD{6} \times \blueD{4}\\\\ &= 24\text{ square centimeters} \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $24$ square centimeters.

question.content: The perimeter of a rectangle is $32$ centimeters.  The width is $7$ centimeters.  **What is the area of the rectangle?**     square centimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.

The perimeter is $\purpleD{32}\text{ cm}$ and the width is $\blueD{7}\text{ cm}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} \purpleD{P} &= \greenD{l} + \blueD{w} + \greenD{l} + \blueD{w}\\\\ \purpleD{32} &= \greenD{\ell} + \blueD7 +  \greenD{\ell} + \blueD7 \\\\ \purpleD{32} &=  \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} + \blueD{14}\\\\ 18&= \greenD{\ell}  + \greenD{\ell} \end{align}$

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 7 centimeters. Under the rectangle, it says Perimeter equals 32 centimeters.

hints.content: What number can we add twice to get $18$?  The length of the rectangle is $\greenD{9}$ centimeters.
Now, we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \greenD{\text{length}} \times \blueD{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \greenD{9} \times \blueD{7}\\\\ &= 63\text{ square centimeters} \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $63$ square centimeters.

question.content: A rectangle has a width of $3$ units.  The rectangle's length is $5$ times its width.    **What is the area of the rectangle?**     square units

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.   $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$
The $\blueD{\text{ width}}$ is $\blueD{3}\text{ units}$ and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $5$ times the $\blueD{\text{width}}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 3 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 5 times 3 units.

hints.content: The $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $5\times\blueD3=\greenD{15}$ units.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 3 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 15 units.

hints.content: Now, we can find the area.  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{Area}} &= \greenD{l} \times \blueD{w}\\\\  &= \greenD{15}\times \blueD{3}\\\\ &=45 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $45$ square units.

question.content: A rectangular playground is $8$ meters wide.  It is $3$ times as long as it is wide.  **What is the area of the playground?**     square meters

hints.content: **Area** is the amount of space a flat shape fills.   $\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{width} \times \text{length}$
The $\blueD{\text{width}}$ is $\blueD{8}\text{ meters}$ and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $3$ times the $\blueD{\text{width}}$.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 8 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 8 times 3 meters.

hints.content: The $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $3\times\blueD{8}=\greenD{24}\text{ meters}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 8 meters and both the top and bottom each labeled 24 meters.

hints.content: Now, we can find the area.  $\begin{align} \goldE{\text{Area}} &= \greenD{l} \times \blueD{w}\\\\  &= \greenD{24}\times \blueD{8}\\\\ &=192 \end{align}$
The area of the playground is $192$ square meters.

question.content: A rectangle has a width of $10$ centimeters.  The rectangle's length is $4$ times its width.    **What is the perimeter of the rectangle?**     centimeters

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.
The $\blueD{\text{width}}$ is $\blueD{10}\text{ cm}$ and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $4$ times the $\blueD{\text{width}}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 10 centimeters and both the top and bottom each labeled 4 times 10 centimeters.

hints.content: The $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $4\times\blueD{10}=\greenD{40}\text{ cm}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 10 centimeters and both the top and bottom each labeled 40 centimeters.

hints.content: Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}} +  \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}}\\\\ &=\greenD{40}+ \blueD{10} + \greenD{40} + \blueD{10}\\\\ &=100 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $100$ centimeters.

question.content: A rectangular sandbox has a width of $5$ units.  The sandbox is $5$ times as long as it is wide.    **What is the perimeter of the sandbox?**     units

hints.content: **Perimeter** is the distance around a closed figure.   We can find the perimeter of a shape by adding all the side lengths.
The $\blueD{\text{width}}$ is $\blueD{5}\text{ units}$ and the $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $5$ times the $\blueD{\text{width}}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 5 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 5 times 5 units.

hints.content: The $\greenD{\text{length}}$ is $5\times\blueD{5}=\greenD{25}$ units.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with both the left and right sides each labeled 5 units and both the top and bottom each labeled 25 units.

hints.content: Now, we can find the perimeter.    $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &= \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}} +  \greenD{\text{ length}} + \blueD{\text{ width}}\\\\ &=\greenD{25}+ \blueD{5} + \greenD{25} + \blueD{5}\\\\ &=60 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the sandbox is $60$ units.
